name: Decline plate sit-up
description: The decline plate sit-up is a weighted core exercise that works the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles, as well as the deep core muscles. Weighted sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
benefits:
Allows you to train in lower rep ranges when bodyweight decline sit-ups become too easy
Weighted ab training can help the core muscles grow and look more defined
Also challenges the shoulders, serratus anterior, upper back, and hip flexors
Can be progressed over time by pressing the weight overhead

name: Seated leg tuck with dumbbell
description: The seated leg tuck with dumbbell is an ab exercise requiring only a bench and a dumbbell. It's commonly performed for high reps as a burnout at the end of a core workout.
benefits:
Works the upper and lower abs in a single movement
Can be performed on a bench or the floor
Inclusion of a dumbbell raises the degree of difficulty

name: Dumbbell V-sit cross jab-
description: The dumbbell V-sit cross jab is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and shoulder muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing a cardiovascular challenge.
benefits:
Strengthens the core to stabilize while the upper body is moving
Great shoulder pump, even with light weights
Excellent cardiovascular and conditioning challenge

name: 30 Flat Bench Leg Raise
description: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Intense burn and contraction of the core muscles
Great for a high-rep ab burnout
Pairs well with other ab movements in circuits

name: 30 Flutter Kick
description: The flutter kick is a core exercise where the legs are held off the ground as you flutter your feet over and under each other in small motions. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Isometric hold builds strength in the abdominals
Serious abdominal activation and burn
Engages lower-body muscles to move feet

name: Chin-up crunch
description: The chin-up crunch is an exercise targeting the core and overall upper-body strength. It combines a chin-up with a knee raise or crunch to give extra emphasis to the core.
benefits:
Builds core and hip flexor strength
Builds strength in the back, biceps, and shoulders
Great carryover to the Army's ACFT leg tuck test
Great way to "sneak" core training into strength training

name: Half Turkish get-up
description: The half Turkish get-up is a kettlebell movement that focuses on the first portion of the Turkish get-up exercise. It is often taught as a precursor to the full Turkish get-up, but is also a valuable abdominal and shoulder exercise in its own right. It can be performed for reps or time, either in lower rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or conditioning.
benefits:
Teaches the most difficult portion of a Turkish get-up
Can use a heavier weight than during a full Turkish get-up
Trains shoulder and core strength and stability in multiple planes of motion
More ab-focused than a full Turkish get-up

name: 30 Hanging Oblique Crunch
description: The hanging oblique crunch an abdominal exercise that targets both the rectus abdominus or “six-pack” muscles, and the oblique muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulder, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another)
benefits:
Targets multiple parts of the abs
Allows you to train in lower strength-focused rep ranges
If performed hanging, can improve grip strength and overhead shoulder mobility

name: 30 Hollow-Body Hold
description: The hollow-body hold is an isometric exercise that increases strength and stability in the core muscles. It is common in gymnastics training, CrossFit training, and as a core tension and bracing drill for lifters and athletes of all types. It is performed for time and can be performed as an activation drill prior to lifting, as part of a circuit, or as equipment-free core training anytime.
benefits:
Teaches proper bracing and core tension
Can be made easier by bending legs and/or arms
Can be made more difficult by straightening legs and/or arms
More difficult than planks
Builds core strength that carries over to lifting and athletics

name: Parallel bars knee raise
description: The parallel bars knee raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on parallel bars, starting in the top position of a dip. Knee raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training.
benefits:
Strengthens the abs and hip flexors
Emphasizes the lower part of the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles
Holding the position on the bars is serious work for the upper body and core

name: BOSU knee tuck
description: The BOSU knee tuck is a dynamic abdominal movement performed on a BOSU ball or other stability training device. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles of the core. It can be performed for time or reps as part of an ab-focused workout or a circuit involving body weight or the BOSU ball.
benefits:
More difficult than bodyweight knee tucks
Stability challenge from the ball forces the abs to work harder to stabilize
Draping back over the ball between reps can increase the stretch on the abs

name: 30 Cable Rope Crunch
description: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
benefits:
Great way to load abs with weight that can be tracked and increased over time
Greater range of motion than a traditional sit-up or crunch
Weighted ab training can increase core definition in addition to strength

name: 30 Cable Rope Oblique Crunch
description: The kneeling cable oblique crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the obliques and rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed for moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
benefits:
Great way to load abs with weight that can be tracked and increased over time
Cable provides constant tension on the targeted muscles
Focuses strictly on the abs without worrying about balance or stability

name: 30 Landmine Twist
description: The landmine twist is a rotational abdominal movement performed utilizing an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. It targets the deep muscles of the core, including both the obliques and the transversus abdominus. It can be done fast or slow, for time or reps, either in traditional muscle-focused rep ranges such as 8-12 reps per side.
benefits:
Maximizes force transfer through the legs, core, and arms
Powerful rotational core training
Trains coordination and power simultaneously

name: Parallel bars leg raise
description: The parallel bars leg raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on parallel bars, starting in the top position of a dip. Leg raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training. However, this difficult variation may require some time to build up to those rep ranges.
benefits:
Strengthens the abs and hip flexors
Emphasizes the lower part of the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles
Holding the position on the bars is serious work for the upper body and core

name: Cable lying twist on ball
description: The cable lying twist on ball is an exercise targeting the core and obliques with the added challenge of stability to keep from losing position on the unstable surface.
benefits:
Builds strength, power, and stability in the abdominals
Engages the lower body and hips to stay in position
Cables allow for constant tension on the muscles

name: Medicine ball Russian twist
description: The medicine ball Russian twist is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise. It targets the oblique muscles, as well as the deep muscles of the core and the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. It can be done for reps or time in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Allows you to train in lower rep ranges when bodyweight twists get too easy
Weighted ab training can help the core muscles grow and look more defined
Trains the core in different planes of motion than crunches or sit-ups

name: 30 Medicine Ball Slam
description: The medicine ball slam is an explosive exercise for developing power, strength, and speed. Muscles worked include the abdominals, legs, triceps, shoulders, and lats. The slams are usually done in rapid succession to complete one set. It can also be a component of a power or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
benefits:
Teaches many muscle groups to work together
Carries over to sports and other lifts
Burns calories and builds conditioning when done for higher reps

name: Otis-up-
description: The Otis-up is a weighted exercise focusing on the abdominal muscles and the shoulders to a lesser degree. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also involves the obliques and deep core muscles. It is normally performed on a decline bench holding a weight plate, but can also be performed with a dumbbell, kettlebell, or other weight.
benefits:
Allows you to train in lower rep ranges when bodyweight decline sit-ups get too easy
Weighted ab training can help the core muscles grow and look more defined
Also challenges the shoulders, serratus anterior, upper back, and hip flexors

name: 30 Cable Pallof Press
description: The pallof press is an anti-rotation, isometric exercise that trains core stability. It is most often seen in programs for athletes who compete in sports that test strength, power, and functional movements.
benefits:
Build abdominal strength and muscular endurance
Works the upper and lower body isometrically to maintain position
Can also be performed with bands if cables unavailable

name: Reverse ab roll-out
description: The reverse ab roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals. It's a twist on the ab wheel roll-out, and is similar to a body saw exercise, only performed on a foam roller. Instead of your arms moving and your lower body remaining stationary, your lower body moves and your arms remain stationary. Beginners may need to use a limited range of motion.
benefits:
Hits every part of the core, including the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles and the deep core muscles
Different stimulus than more traditional moves such as the crunch and reverse crunch
Great anti-extension core training

name: 30 Seated Twist With PVC Pipe
description: The seated bar twist is a core exercise aiming to strengthen the obliques.
benefits:
Stronger obliques carries over into any turning or bending mvoements
Promotes overall core stability
Contributes to better core aesthetics

name: 30 Shoulder Tap
description: The shoulder tap is an exercise targeting the abdominals and core. The basic stance matches the top of a push-up position. From there, one hand is raised to tap its opposing shoulder. A tap with each hand to each opposing shoulder equals one rep.
benefits:
Great for working the abdominals and core, as well as the shoulders
Harder than traditional straight-arm planks because of switching between single arms for support
Can be performed by all fitness levels

name: 30 Side Plank On Ball
description: The feet-elevated side plank on ball is a more advanced version of a traditional bodyweight side plank. The feet are balanced on an exercise ball, providing a balance challenge but also increasing the load placed upon the obliques and shoulder muscles. It is usually performed for timed holds, either one side at a time or alternating sides. If a ball is unavailable, some of the benefits of the movement can be obtained by performing side planks with the feet elevated on a couch, chair, bench, or other stable object.
benefits:
Strengthens the lateral musculature of the body, including the obliques and external hips
Powerful isometric contraction for the deep core muscles, including the transversus abdominis
Can be further progressed by performing with a straight bottom arm

name: Smith machine V-up
description: The smith machine V-up is a weighted abdominal exercise that involves pressing a weighted bar upward while performing a V-up. Performing it in a Smith machine eliminates the balance challenge of a free weight. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps in the ab-focused portion of a workout.
benefits:
Allows you to train in lower rep ranges when bodyweight V-ups become too easy
Weighted ab training can help the core muscles grow and look more defined
Increases abdominal strength, not just muscle tone

name: 30 Spider Crawl
description: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
benefits:
Intense challenge even with no added weight
Engrains cross-body gait pattern and athletic coordination
Challenges the shoulders, core, legs, arms, and back

name: Spider crunch
description: The spider crunch is a core exercise that begins in a straight-arm plank position and involves raising one knee toward your same-side elbow to target the obliques. It is similar to a mountain climber, but with the knees out wider. It can be performed for time or reps as bodyweight ab training or conditioning.
benefits:
Builds core strength and stability
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Teaches core to brace while upper and lower body move

name: Suspended crunch-
description: The suspended crunch is an abdominal exercise performed with the feet in the stirrups of a suspension strap system. It targets the muscles of the core, most prominently the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also taxes the shoulders and deep core muscles.
benefits:
Similar to a mountain climber, but with more constant tension on abs
Intense stretch and contraction of abdominal muscles
Powerful isometric work for shoulders and upper back, similar to a plank

name: Suspended oblique crunch
description: The suspended oblique crunch is an abdominal exercise performed with the feet in the stirrups of a suspension strap system. It targets the muscles of the core, most prominently the obliques, but also the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, the shoulders, and deep core muscles.
benefits:
Intense stretch and contraction of multiple abdominal muscles
Powerful isometric work for shoulders and upper back, similar to a plank
Constant tension on obliques and other ab muscles throughout movement

name: Toe-touch
description: The toe-touch is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Strengthens the abs and hip flexors
Demands hip flexor and quad strength to keep legs straight
Constant tension on the abs throughout the movement
Requires no equipment

name: 30 Hanging Toes-To-Bar
description: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement: strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent, each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
benefits:
Builds serious core strength that carries over to a wide range of lifts
Forces coordination and co-contraction of the lats, shoulders, core, and hip flexors
Builds hamstring flexibility when done strictly
Can be trained in lower strength-focused rep ranges than many other ab exercise

name: 30 V-Up
description: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Strengthens the abs and hip flexors
Increases core strength and stability
More difficult than standard crunches or reverse crunches
Requires no equipment

name: Weighted sit-up
description: The weighted sit-up is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the sit-up far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training and helping build strong abs.
benefits:
Allows you to train in lower rep ranges when bodyweight sit-ups become too easy
Weighted ab training can help the core muscles grow and look more defined
Increases abdominal strength, not just muscle tone

name: Medicine ball twist
description: The medicine ball twist is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the obliques. It is similar in many ways to a Russian twist exercise. The ball is held tight to the chest throughout the movement, and then the torso is rotated from side to side for the desired number of reps or a set amount of time.
benefits:
Works the obliques dynamically and the rectus abdominis isometrically
Squeezing the ball co-contracts the chest, potentially making the core work harder
Pairs well with other movements in a core circuit

name: Hanging exercise ball leg raise
description: The hanging exercise ball leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs and hip flexors. Instead of resting the forearms on the pads of an apparatus, it's performed hanging from a bar with an exercise ball held between the legs.
benefits:
Higher degree of difficulty than with the captain's chair or parallel bars
Produces a major burn in the midsection
Can be performed anywhere with a bar to hang from

name: Cocoon crunch
description: The cocoon crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing your knees to your chest and your arms from overhead to center. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Builds the rectus abdominis and the obliques
Both stretches and contracts ab muscles
Difficulty increased by moving both arms and legs simultaneously
No equipment required

name: Bench oblique crunch
description: The bench oblique crunch is an exercise that targets the obliques, the muscles running alongside the rectus abdominis. The range of motion is fairly small, but it still does a great job of working these hard-to-isolate muscles. Like most crunch variations, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
benefits:
Works the obliques
Easy to learn and master
The balance challenge of staying on the bench may make the core muscles work harder

name: 30 Cable Reverse Crunch On Ball
description: The cable reverse crunch on a BOSU is performed on top of a BOSU ball between two cable pulleys, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically and is more proprioceptively challenging than a cable reverse crunch on the floor.
benefits:
Building core strength and stability
Engages the low and upper back to maintain spinal stability
Cables allow for constant tension on the muscles
Using a BOSU creates more of a stabilization challenge for the core

name: Standing Low-Cable Row - Abel Albonetti Version
30 Cable Reverse Crunch
description: The cable reverse crunch is performed on the ground facing away from a high pulley, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically.
benefits:
Building core strength and stability
Engages the low and upper back to maintain spinal stability
Cables allow for constant tension on the muscles

name: Full moon-
description: The full moon is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs. It is similar to a V-up, but with the added challenge of “drawing” a circle shape in the air during each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Added challenge beyond standard V-ups
Intense isometric and dynamic core work for rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles, and obliques
Strengthens both abs and hip flexors

name: 30 Decline Press Sit-Up
description: The decline bar press sit-up is a core and upper body exercise targeting the lower abdominals and shoulders.
benefits:
Builds strength and stability in the rectus abdominus
Builds strength and size in the deltoids
Can be progressed by increasing the decline angle over time or adding weight

name: Push-up to side plank
description: The push-up to side plank is an upper-body and core-focused exercise combining two popular bodyweight movements. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders with the push-up, and the obliques and hip external rotator muscles with the side plank. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or any bodyweight strength-training workout.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core
Strengthens the abdominals, mainly targeting the obliques
Improves shoulder and hip stability

Total Fitness Ab Tuck
description: The hollow-body knee tuck is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to both the hollow-body hold and the knee tuck or reverse crunch, combining elements of both. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
benefits:
Combines isometric and dynamic abdominal training
Targets the six-pack muscles, but also the obliques and hip flexors
Great for variety if you've been doing standard hollow-body holds or knee tucks

name: Active hang from bar
description: The active hang from bar is a static exercise that involves isometrically squeezing the shoulders into the sockets and activating the muscles of the upper back and core. It can be used to improve pull-up form or to do more pull-ups, but also has postural and shoulder health benefits.
benefits:
Builds grip, upper back, and core strength that can carry over into pull-ups
Teaches proper shoulder position that can carry over to a wide range of strength exercise
Activates important postural muscles
Can improve overhead shoulder mobility and stability

name: Total Fitness Bear Crawl
description: The bear crawl is a popular bodyweight crawling exercise. While it looks simple, the bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
benefits:
Cardiovascular and muscular challenge even with no added weight
Engrains cross-body gait pattern and athletic coordination
Challenges the shoulders, core, legs, arms, and back

name: Bootstrapper squat
description: The bootstrapper squat is a movement that improves mobility, muscular strength, and flexibility in the hips and hamstrings. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the lower body to mobilize the hips and improve squat form.
benefits:
Increases mobility and flexibility in the hips, hamstrings, and glutes
Great dynamic warm-up before loaded squats or deadlifts
Activates the quads and hip and back muscles

name: Total Fitness Broad Jump
description: The broad jump is an explosive lower-body exercise. It is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the farther you'll be able to jump.
benefits:
Builds and demonstrates strength and power in the glutes, hamstrings, and quads
Improves acceleration, balance, and coordination
Common in training for track, running, or football
Can be an effective "contrast" exercise paired with heavy deadlifts or squats to boost power
Requires no equipment

name: Cat-cow
description: Cat-cow is a traditional yoga pose that is also popular in fitness and strength training. It targets spinal mobility and control of the vertebral column. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or as a mobility or restorative exercise anytime. It can also work as part of a yoga or bodyweight sequence with other poses.
benefits:
Helps boost thoracic mobility and overall spinal control
Requires no equipment
Can be done by people of all fitness levels
Not physically taxing; can be performed as a restorative exercise
Excellent way to limber up a stiff spine in the morning or before exercise

name: Total Fitness Close-Grip Dumbbell Press
description: The close-grip dumbbell bench press puts a spin on a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. It’s a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. The difference here is that the dumbbells are held closer together.
benefits:
Targets the pectorals and triceps to a similar degree
Also works the deltoids, particularly the front heads
One side can’t compensate for the other, as in the barbell bench press

name: Crab walk
description: The crab walk is a full-body exercise that has been popular in schools and gym classes for decades. It's a full-body coordination challenge that also burns serious calories, making it an excellent inclusion in a full-body warm-up or bodyweight circuit workout.
benefits:
Builds full-body muscular coordination and endurance
Increase strength and stability in the core, hips, and shoulders
Great for added variety to high-intensity training
Effective warm-up for training or sports that can be performed anywhere

name: Dumbbell racked carry
description: The dumbbell racked carry involves carrying dumbbells for time or distance, while holding them close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
benefits:
Strengthens and challenges the grip, core, biceps, upper back, shoulders, and legs
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Less complex to learn and perform properly than many other popular strength movements
Builds muscular coordination and mental toughness in addition to strength and muscle

name: Dumbbell clean and push-press
description: The dumbbell clean and push-press is a full-body movement that targets both the lower and upper body. The clean utilizes the muscles of the hips, legs, glutes, back, and biceps, while the push-press utilizes the shoulders and triceps. It differs from the clean and press in that the push-press allows you to use lower-body momentum to power through the most difficult part of the press. It can be trained in low to moderate reps for strength, or for higher reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, for muscle building or metabolic conditioning.
benefits:
Mainly works the quads, hamstrings, glutes, shoulders, back, and core
Works the squat and overhead positions
The push-press allows for more weight to be used and enhanced power output
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn

name: Total Fitness Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
description: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
benefits:
Strengthens and challenges the grip, core, traps, upper back, shoulders, and legs
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Less complex to learn and perform properly than many other popular strength movements
Builds muscular coordination and mental toughness in addition to strength and muscle
If grip strength is a limiting factor, lifting straps can still enable you to use heavy weights

name: Total Fitness Dumbbell Isometric Row Hold
description: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
benefits:
Forces the core muscles to stabilize while the upper body is moving
Trains back and grip strength, as well as hips and glutes from holding the bent-over position
Boosts the heart rate and creates cardiovascular challenge during strength training

name: Dumbbell kickstand deadlift
description: The dumbbell kickstand deadlift is a movement targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. The kickstand position can help focus the stretch and contraction on each individual leg, similar to a single-leg Romanian deadlift, while presenting less of a balance challenge. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, for strengthening the posterior chain, or for higher reps for muscle growth.
benefits:
May allow a greater stretch in hamstrings than two-legged Romanian deadlift
Great accessory movement for the barbell deadlift
Strengthens and builds active flexibility in the glutes and hamstrings

name: Dumbbell racked reverse lunge
description: The dumbbell racked reverse lunge is a popular lower-body movement that targets the muscles of the quads, glutes, hamstrings, and hips. Holding dumbbells in the racked position further challenges the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Lunge variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing split squats instead.
benefits:
Creates less torque in the front knee and better stability with the front leg as the stationary leg
The racked position forces the core to work harder to keep from rounding forward as you lunge
Helps improve hip flexibility and core stability

name: Dumbbell renegade row
description: The dumbbell renegade row combines rowing and core training into a single difficult movement. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts, as well as in circuit-style training.
benefits:
Only requires one light pair of weights, but significantly works the core, back, and shoulders
Forces the core muscles to work hard to stabilize throughout the sequence
Boosts the heart rate and creates a cardiovascular challenge during strength training

name: Total Fitness Dumbbell Reverse Lunge
description: The dumbbell reverse lunge is a great single-leg movement that strengthens and builds the quads, hamstrings, and glutes.
benefits:
Front leg as stationary leg helps maintain stability better than forward lunges
Less torque on the front knee
Helps improve balance hip flexibility, core stability, and overall functionality

name: Dumbbell row to triceps kick-back
description: The dumbbell row to triceps kick-back is a dumbbell complex that combines two movements that collectively target the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi), upper back, and triceps. It also isometrically targets the core, hamstrings, and glutes. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit two crucial upper-body muscles in any workout.
benefits:
Adds size and strength in lats and upper back
Great way to make shoulder training more athletic
Isometrically works the core and posterior chain

name: Single-arm dumbbell floor press
description: The single-arm dumbbell floor press is a multijoint pressing exercise performed lying on the floor, either with the knees bent or straight. It has less range of motion than a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. By performing it with one arm, you can strengthen weakness on certain sides or simply use it as a way to challenge the core more during this exercise.
benefits:
Builds chest and triceps size and strength
Free hand can help perform forced reps
Takes your legs out of the movement, giving all the responsibility to your core and upper body

name: Single-arm dumbbell snatch-
description: The single-arm dumbbell snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. It involves lifting a dumbbell from the ground to overhead in a single movement. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
benefits:
Full-body power training without special equipment
Works the quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, and shoulders
Great alternative to the barbell snatch

name: Total Fitness Dumbbell Step-Up
description: The dumbbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. The dumbbell version is better for intermediate and advanced lifters than beginners, who should begin by performing these unweighted.
benefits:
Builds lower-body strength and power
Improves balance
Mercilessly reveals any muscle and strength imbalances between the legs

name: Floor angel
description: The floor angel is a stretch targeting shoulder mobility and activation of the shoulder stabilizer muscles. It also targets a range of postural muscles in the upper back.
benefits:
Activates rotator cuffs and many muscles in the shoulders and upper back
Requires no equipment
Can contribute to improved mobility and range of motion in shoulders
Can contribute to better form on overhead work and all types of presses

name: Lunge with overhead reach
description: The lunge with overhead reach is a full-body bodyweight movement targeting the quads and shoulders. It has both strength and mobility benefits and can be performed one leg at a time or alternating for time or for reps.
benefits:
Builds stability in the shoulders and hips and strengthens the lower body
Improves overhead mobility and thoracic flexibility
Can be used as a dynamic warm-up for full-body and overhead movements

name: Total Fitness Hamstring Slide
description: The hamstring slide is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hamstrings. Lying supine on a smooth surface, you bend your knees to pull both heels toward you. The sliding action requires a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under the heel. These are considered more difficult than exercise ball hamstring curls, and are a great primer movement before heavy squats or deadlifts, or as an accessory movement later in a lower-body workout.
benefits:
Builds and strengthens the hamstrings
Trains knee flexion function of hamstrings
Great high-rep burnout movement or primer before strenght training

name: Hang from bar
description: The hang from bar is a static exercise that involves hanging from a bar by two hands. It can either be an "active hang," where you pack the shoulders and activate the muscles of the upper back, or a "passive hang," where you let the shoulders unpack and let the muscles of the upper body stretch. A passive hang may not be appropriate for all people depending on their shoulder health, but many coaches believe hanging can be healthy for the shoulders when done properly.
benefits:
Effective stretch for the lats, shoulders, and pecs
Builds grip strength that can carry over to pull-ups and other bar exercises
Can improve overhead shoulder mobility and stability

name: Total Fitness Hollow Hold
description: The hollow-body hold is an isometric exercise that increases strength and stability in the core muscles. It is common in gymnastics training, CrossFit training, and as a core tension and bracing drill for lifters and athletes of all types. It is performed for time and can be performed as an activation drill prior to lifting, as part of a circuit, or as equipment-free core training anytime.
benefits:
Teaches proper bracing and core tension
Can be made easier by bending legs and/or arms
Can be made more difficult by straightening legs and/or arms
More difficult than planks
Builds core strength that carries over to lifting and athletics

name: Jump to pull-up
description: The jump to pull-up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the muscles of the back, biceps, and, to a lesser degree, legs. It involves jumping up to a pull-up bar between reps. Similar to a push-press, the legs help power through the most difficult portion of the pull-up, allowing you to perform more reps. Jumping pull-ups are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as an accessory to other pulling or pull-up training, or as a full-body movement in a circuit or metcon.
benefits:
Strengthens the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, upper back, core, and grip
Allows you to perform pull-ups for high reps
Provides a serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn when done for high reps
Effective way to get into position to perform pull-up negative reps

name: Total Fitness Lateral Lunge
description: The lateral lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that works the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It is often performed for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility routine but can also work in a circuit or other workouts.
benefits:
Builds strength, stability, and balance
Stretches and trains the adductors and abductors
Strengthens stabilizer muscles for other exercises or sports involving lateral movement

name: Lateral shuffle
description: The lateral shuffle is a common exercise in sports training and gym classes. It involves taking steps to one side and then steps to the other side. It can be performed as part of a circuit for athletes of any level, but is also a great movement for beginners.
benefits:
Great dynamic warm-up
Common drill for basketball and other sports
Raises core temperature
Activates and mobilizes hips and glutes

name: Pigeon stretch
description: The pigeon stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is similar to the pigeon pose from yoga, but is also popular as part of dynamic warm-ups or cool-downs in strength training. It can also be performed anytime to help combat training-related soreness.
benefits:
Improves flexibility and mobility in the hips and glutes
Can relieve tension in the lower back and hips
Improved mobility in hips leads to better performance in lower-body movements

name: Total Fitness Plyo Push-Up
description: The plyo push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core
Targets the powerful fast-twitch muscle fibers
Carries over to increased speed and strength in pressing movements

name: Rolling triceps press
description: The rolling triceps press is a dynamic triceps exercise that is popular as a bench press accessory movement among powerlifters. It can be done in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, or for very high reps of 50-100 reps per set to boost triceps size and strength. It can be performed on a bench or on the floor if a bench is unavailable.
benefits:
Stretches and strengthens all three heads of the triceps, including the long head
"Rolling" the weights overhead targets the long head specifically
May be more elbow-friendly for some people than skullcrushers
Can be done as an accessory movement or a high-rep burnout

name: Scapular push-up
description: The scapular push-up is an upper-body exercise aimed at increasing the stability of the scapulae and mobility in the shoulders. It is often performed as part of a dynamic warm-up before an upper-body workout, or as part of a mobility session.
benefits:
Improved shoulder health and function
Increases core strength and stability
Teaches both retraction and protraction of scapulae, which is essential for shoulder health

name: Bent-over scapular slide
description: The bent-over scapular slide is an upper-body exercise that helps with scapular and shoulder mobility. It is commonly performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for the upper body.
benefits:
Can help prepare shoulders for lifting and avoid or work through injury
Carries over into stronger and safer overhead pressing movements
Can also be done with your back against a wall
Warm-up for core and back in addition to shoulders

name: Shoulder extension stretch
description: The shoulder extension stretch is focused on bringing more flexibility to the shoulder joint. It increases range of motion in shoulder extension, or moving the arms behind the back. It can be performed as part of a warm-up or mobility and flexibility work post-workout or anytime.
benefits:
Increases range of motion in shoulders
Stretches biceps and activates upper back
Carries over to pressing movements like dips and the bench press

name: Total Fitness Side Plank
description: The side plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It is sometimes paired with the curl up and bird dog as the “McGill big three” for core strength and stability. It is performed for time and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Builds core stability and strength, particularly in the deep core and obliques
Trains often-neglected lateral muscle chains of body
Strengthens hip external rotation and knee stability
Easy to regress by placing feet in front of one another
Easy to progress by floating upper leg and/or straightening supporting arm

name: Iron cross stretch
description: The iron cross stretch is a bodyweight stretch that focuses on hip and thoracic spine mobility.
benefits:
Opens up thoracic spine
Requires no equipment
Stretches glutes and hip muscles
A step or bolster can be used to limit stretch until mobility improves

name: Side plank pulse
description: The side plank pulse is a dynamic version of the side plank exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It can be performed for time or reps and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Builds core stability and strength, particularly in the deep core and obliques
Trains often-neglected lateral muscle chains of body
Strengthens hip external rotation and knee stability
Pulsing motion maintains constant tension on ab muscles

name: Single-arm dumbbell front squat
description: The single-arm dumbbell front squat is an exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, as well as the upper body. It also challenges oblique strength due to the offset loading. It can be performed in strength and muscle-focused workouts, in circuit training, or as part of a larger dumbbell complex with movements like single-arm dumbbell clean and presses.
benefits:
Encourages squatting with good form and an upright torso
Effective even with heavy dumbbells
Serious challenge to biceps, core, and upper back

name: Single-arm dumbbell racked carry
description: The single-arm dumbbell racked carry involves carrying a single dumbbell for time or distance, while holding it close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
benefits:
Strengthens and challenges the grip, core, biceps, upper back, shoulders, and legs
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Provides significant core and oblique challenges due to the single-sided loading
Builds muscular coordination and mental toughness in addition to strength and muscle

name: Total Fitness Skip
description: The skip is an exercise that builds power and explosiveness in the legs. It's commonly performed by children and in gym classes, but is also great for working the legs and hip flexors, making it a favorite warm-up for athletes who need to explode vertically.
benefits:
Classic dynamic warm-up for athletics and training
Trains jumping muscles including ankles, hips, and legs
Simple, effective bodyweight movement for a conditioning circuit
Requires no equipment

name: Total Fitness Spider Crawl (Unweighted)
description: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
benefits:
Intense challenge even with no added weight
Engrains cross-body gait pattern and athletic coordination
Challenges the shoulders, core, legs, arms, and back

name: Total Fitness Spider Lunge
description: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
benefits:
Improves flexibility and mobility in the hips
Stretches the chronically tight adductor group
Simple way to limber up before lifting or athletics

name: Spider lunge stretch
description: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
benefits:
Improves flexibility and mobility in the hips
Stretches the chronically tight adductor group
Simple way to limber up before lifting or athletics

name: Spider lunge with T-rotation
description: The spider lunge with T-rotation is an exercise that produces a deep stretch in the glutes and hamstrings while also rotating and mobilizing the thoracic spine region. It is a great movement to include in a dynamic warm-up, or as mobility work anytime.
benefits:
Great stretch for the hamstrings and glutes
Hits areas, like thoracic mobility, that most stretches don't
Improves coordination and body awareness

name: Standing quad stretch
description: The standing quad stretch is a simple exercise designed to stretch the quadriceps, the big muscles that cover most of the thighs. This is a static stretch, meaning it’s usually performed by holding the stretched position for a certain length of time.
benefits:
Suitable for beginners
Pairs well with other dynamic warm-ups in a circuit
Relieves tightness and increases flexibility in the quadriceps

name: Total Fitness V-Up
description: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Strengthens the abs and hip flexors
Increases core strength and stability
More difficult than standard crunches or reverse crunches
Requires no equipment

name: Vertical jump
description: The vertical jump is an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
benefits:
Builds and demonstrates strength and power in the glutes, hamstrings, and quads
Improves speed, agility, and power output
Common in training for track, running, or football
Can be an effective "contrast" exercise paired with heavy deadlifts or squats to boost power

name: Standing dumbbell knee crunch
description: The standing dumbbell knee crunch is a great way to train the abs while standing up. Additionally, the deltoids are worked because the lifter holds a pair of dumbbells overhead throughout.
benefits:
Strengthens the core
Strengthens the shoulders
Burns a lot of calories efficiently

name: Total Fitness Weighted Push-Up
description: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
benefits:
Great for building the chest and triceps
The weight plates allow for progressive resistance on a bodyweight exercise
Can be performed as a dropset with bodyweight push-ups

name: Jordan Shallow Foam Roller Thoracic Extension
Jordan Shallow Thread the Needle (with Foam Roller)
Jordan Shallow Band-Resisted Thread the Needle
King Maker Pull-Up
description: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of “relative strength” which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
benefits:
Strengthens the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, upper back, core, and grip
Requires no equipment other than a bar
Can build absolute strength for low reps, or strength endurance for higher reps
Easy to alter grip style and width to target different muscles or rep ranges

name: King Maker Push-up
description: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and abdominals
Increases core strength and hip stability
Engages lower-body muscles to maintain plank position
Easy to regress or progress by raising or lowering torso
Can add pauses or manipulate tempo to increase difficulty

name: Warrior push-up
description: The warrior push-up is a series of push-up and plank variations combined into a single sequence. They include a Judo push-up, plank, side plank, mountain climber, diamond push-up, and regular push-up. Done together, they tax the upper-body muscles from different angles and increase time under tension for the entire body.
benefits:
Challenges chest, triceps, and shoulders from multiple angles
Requires greater coordination and time under tension than a simple set of push-ups
Can be done for time or reps

name: King Maker Burpee
description: The burpee is a high-intensity exercise that recruits the entire body to build strength and aerobic capacity. It is common in CrossFit workouts and group fitness classes, but can also be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
benefits:
Builds muscular endurance and strength in the lower and upper body
Requires core and lower-back strength to keep a neutral spine on the push-up and jump
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds endurance, balance, and coordination
Can be performed for high reps for a serious challenge
Requires no equipment

name: King Maker Barbell Bench Press
description: The bench press is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest and triceps. When many people think of listing, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind
benefits:
Builds and strengthens the lower body
Also hits the shoulders, particularly the front heads
Core needs to activate to perform reps

name: King Maker Incline Barbell Bench Press
description: The incline bench press is an upper body compound movement that targets the upper chest.
benefits:
Builds chest size and strength
Works the triceps and anterior deltoids
Core and lower body engagement to maintain position and increase pressing strength

name: King Maker Barbell Back Squat
description: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
benefits:
Adds size and strength to the quads, glutes, and hamstrings
Requires back and core strength to maintain torso positioning
Can be used to improve conditioning and cardiovascular health
Considered by many to be "the king of exercises"

name: King Maker Barbell Thruster
description: The barbell thruster is a full-body exercise that incorporates both squatting and pressing in one functional movement. It's especially common in contemporary CrossFit workouts, but also in general strength training. The barbell is usually cleaned into place first, but it could be performed taken from a squat rack in a front-rack position. The thruster can be performed in traditional strength-focused rep ranges to build strength in the press, or in higher reps for full-body conditioning.
benefits:
Front squat develops quads, hamstrings, glutes, and core strength
Overhead press works shoulders, triceps, and upper back
Can be a strength move or a metcon, depending on rep range
Squat helps push through the sticking point of the press

name: King Maker Barbell Deadlift
description: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
benefits:
Primarily targets the back, hamstrings, and glutes, but also brings in the lats, traps, and forearms
Builds core strength and stability
Can be beneficial even at light or moderate weights
Simple to scale for non-powerlifters by raising the bar to where someone can perform it without flexing their lower back
If grip is a limitation, it can be performed with a mixed grip or using straps

name: Single-arm incline cable cross-over
description: The single-arm incline cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a bench to target the upper part of the pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
benefits:
Unlike dumbbells, cables provide constant tension, including at peak contraction
Can quickly switch weights for dropsets
The line of resistance from the cables targets the muscles of the upper pectorals
Stretches the chest muscles under load which can lead to greater muscle gain

name: Dumbbell goblet squat-
description: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise in which a dumbbell or kettlebell is held in front of the chest with two hands, approximating how you might hold a heavy goblet. It is used as a teaching tool to help instruct and develop proper squat form, but is also effective for building size in the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for low reps to build strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and conditioning.
benefits:
Encourages squatting with good form and an upright torso
Targets the quads and glutes, especially when performed for high reps
Encourages hip mobility and full-body coordination
Great squat variation for lifters of all ability levels

name: King Maker Dumbbell Lateral Raise
description: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
benefits:
Builds shoulder strength and size, even with light weights
Makes shoulders appear wider and rounder
Can be done standing or seated

name: Dumbbell shadow boxing
description: Dumbbell shadow boxing is a more advanced version of a popular conditioning exercise. By adding a pair of lightweight dumbbells, you can greatly increase the challenge to both the shoulders and cardiovascular system.
benefits:
Increased metabolic burn and conditioning
Can help you punch faster and harder
Strengthens the grip, shoulders, core, and upper back

name: King Maker Standing Dumbbell Shoulder Press
description: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-builder (especially the front deltoids) that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows for more weight to be used.
benefits:
Dumbbells prevent one shoulder from compensating for weakness in the other
The more natural range of motion vs. the barbell version lowers injury risk
Stronger shoulders help with a multitude of other lifts, as well as sports

name: King Maker Weighted Jump Squat
description: The dumbbell jump squat takes a classic bodybuilding move, the squat, and adds a plyometric element, the jump. It builds not only lower-body strength but also explosiveness.
benefits:
Continuous up-and-down movement maximizes fat burning
Increase explosive power
Improve balance
Build leg muscle

name: King Maker Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
description: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
benefits:
Strengthens and challenges the grip, core, traps, upper back, shoulders, and legs
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Less complex to learn and perform properly than many other popular strength movements
Builds muscular coordination and mental toughness in addition to strength and muscle
If grip strength is a limiting factor, lifting straps can still enable you to use heavy weights

name: King Maker Dumbbell Shrug
description: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It’s a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
benefits:
Simple to set up and perform
With the help of lifting straps, you can go very heavy
Easy to add intensity by pausing for 1-3 seconds at the top of the movement

name: King Maker Lat Pull-Down
description: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
benefits:
Targets the latissimus dorsi muscles
Cable allows for continuous tension
Easy to learn and execute

name: King Maker Leg Press
description: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
benefits:
Build stronger, more muscular quadriceps
Safer for the spine than squatting with bad form
Can accommodate quite a bit of weight without needing a spotter

name: King Maker Resistance Band Leg Press
Single-leg leg press
description: The single-leg leg press is a machine exercise targeting the leg muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The leg press is often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
benefits:
Builds stronger, more muscular quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings
Can accommodate quite a bit of weight without needing a spotter
Great for high-rep leg training
Changing foot placement or toe angle can change the emphasis of the exercise
Allows you to focus on each leg individually and address imbalances

name: King Maker Hack Squat
description: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
benefits:
Builds size and strength in the quads, glutes, and hamstrings
Great heavy movement or lighter-weight burnout
Changing foot placement or toe angle can change the emphasis of the exercise

name: Barbell bear complex
description: The barbell bear complex is a series of barbell lifts that run together in a single sequence: a barbell power clean, front squat, push-press, back squat, and another push-press from behind the neck. It trains the entire body for both building strength and improving conditioning. It is often performed for rounds, either with or without rest between rounds.
benefits:
Combines cardiovascular and strength training
Good for developing efficiency with several barbell movements
Teaches coordination and moving the body as one unit
Great carryover to other lifts and athletics

name: Barbell deadlift bent-over row complex
description: The barbell deadlift bent-over row complex combines two movements to target the posterior chain. It requires using a lighter weight than you could handle for heavy deadlifts alone, but doubles down on activation in the upper back, lower back, and glutes.
benefits:
Strengthens and builds the hamstrings, glutes, and lower and upper back
Teaches coordination and moving the body as one unit
Adds a cardiovascular and conditioning challenge to strength work

name: King Maker Explosive High Jump
description: The tuck jump is a vertical jump, an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
benefits:
Builds and demonstrates strength and power in the glutes, hamstrings, and quads
Improves speed, agility, and power output
Common in training for track, running, or football
Can be an effective "contrast" exercise paired with heavy deadlifts or squats to boost power

name: Jay Dumbbell Thruster to Reverse Lunge
Jay Broad Jump to High Knees
30 Shoulders Bent-Over Low Cable Reverse Fly
30 Shoulders Incline Face-Down Dumbbell Reverse Fly
30 Shoulders Incline Face-Up Straight-Bar Front Raise
30 Shoulders Single-Arm Bent-Over Cable Reverse Fly
30 Shoulders Single-Arm Leaning Cable Lateral Raise
30 Shoulders Seated Banded Barbell Shoulder Press
Smith machine push-up
description: The Smith machine push-up is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It is similar in form to bodyweight push-ups, but with the hands on the bar of the Smith machine. This allows you to vary the height to increase or decrease difficulty, or to perform a mechanical dropset by raising the bar after hitting failure at a certain height.
benefits:
Increased overall upper-body strength
Can vary the difficulty by raising or lowering the height of the bar
Easy to perform mechanical dropsets
Great for performing hands-elevated push-ups

name: 30 Chest Smith Machine Incline Chest Press
3D dumbbell lunge
description: The 3D dumbbell lunge is a sequence of lower-body exercises that target the muscles of the glutes, quads, and hamstrings from a variety of angles. It consists of one curtsy lunge with each leg, followed by one reverse lunge with each leg. This lunge variation is most commonly performed for multiple rounds as part of a lower-body circuit or workout.
benefits:
Builds size and muscular endurance in the quads, glutes, and hamstrings
Develops core strength and hip stability to maintain proper positioning of torso
Works muscles in different planes of motion

name: MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge To Squat
MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge With High Knee
MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row With Dumbbell Pull-Through
MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row With Push-Up
Alternating sit-through with crunch-
description: The alternating sit-through with crunch is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you perform a crunch. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
benefits:
Builds strength and size in the shoulders and chest
Increases core strength and stability
Trains shoulder extension and stability
Greater challenge to the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles than traditional sit-throughs

name: MetaBurn Bent-Over Row to Rear-Delt Raise
Dumbbell jump squat with rotation
description: The dumbbell jump squat with rotation is a popular movement combining an explosive lower-body movement with extra upper-body loading in the form of dumbbells held in the hands. Each jump ends with the body turned 90 degrees, adding a rotational power component to the lift. It is usually performed with light weights for high reps in fat-loss and conditioning workouts.
benefits:
Simple way to increase the challenge of jump squats
Serious cardiovascular challenge and calorie burn
Builds leg muscle and power
Improves balance and athleticism

name: MetaBurn Dumbbell Wide Squat to Rack
MetaBurn Hammer Curl to Overhead Press
MetaBurn Judo Push-Up To Pike Push-Up
MetaBurn Plank To Alternating Side Plank
MetaBurn Reverse Lunge To High Pull
MetaBurn Reverse Lunge With Overhead Raise
Single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row
description: The single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row takes two popular strength moves and combines them into one full-body blaster. Between the deadlift and the row, you'll target the glutes, hamstrings, quads, back, and biceps. Because balance can be a challenge, this movement is usually done with relatively light weights for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
benefits:
Strengthens the entire posterior chain in a single sequence
Simple way to get a lot of work out of relatively light weights
Challenges and builds balance and coordination

name: Standing dumbbell knee crunch-
description: The standing dumbbell knee crunch is a great way to train the abs while standing up. Additionally, the deltoids are worked because the lifter holds a pair of dumbbells overhead throughout.
benefits:
Strengthens the core
Strengthens the shoulders
Burns a lot of calories efficiently

name: MetaBurn Tuck Jump With Knee Slap
X-body V-up
description: The X-body V-up is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to the popular V-up exercise, but is performed with the arms and legs out wide in an X-shape. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
benefits:
Serious abdominal activation and burn
Targets the six-pack muscles, but also the obliques and hip flexors
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds explosiveness, balance, and coordination

name: MetaBurn Biceps Curl To Lateral Raise
30 Back Standing Low Cable Bar Row
30 Back Standing Low Cable Rope Row
RG 3-Way Single-Arm Rear Delt Cable Fly
RG Alternating Seated Dumbbell Lateral Raise
RG Single-Arm Cross-Body Cable Front Raise
FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift to Dumbbell Upright Row
FYR2 Fire Feet with Burpee Tuck Jump Drill
FYR2 Glute Bridge Dumbbell Floor Press
FYR2 Kettlebell High Pull to Overhead Press
FYR2 Kettlebell Reverse Lunge Switch Grip
FYR2 Kettlebell Reverse Lunge to Kneeling Press
FYR2 Kettlebell Swing Clean and Press
Levitating side kick-through
description: The levitating side kick-through is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you kick into the air in a partial handstand. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
benefits:
Increases upper-body strength and muscular endurance
Increases core strength, as well as full-body coordination and balance
Improves coordination, balance, and stability

name: Lunge high-knee clap
description: The lunge high-knee clap is a full-body, cardio-based exercise with emphasis on the lower body. It includes a clap under the front leg to make the movement more powerful and strict. It can be performed either for time or reps and is a great inclusion in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
benefits:
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds endurance, balance, and coordination
Works core strength to maintain balance and a neutral spine
Engages the arms, hip flexors, and lower-body muscles

name: FYR2 Push-Up to Kettlebell Hike Combo
FYR2 Reverse Burpee to Regular Burpee
FYR2 Reverse Lunge to Single-Leg Kettlebell Deadlift
Single-arm kettlebell row-
description: The single-arm kettlebell row is a popular muscle- and strength-building exercise that works the muscles of the back and core simultaneously. It has all the same benefits as a single-arm dumbbell row, but some people find a kettlebell more comfortable to hold during the movement.
benefits:
Trains the muscles of the upper back one at a time, allowing you to focus on each side
The muscles of the core must work hard to resist rotation
The muscles of the lower back and glutes also contract isometrically during the set

name: FYR2 Superhero Lunge Squat Clean and Press
30 Arms Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension
BFR underhand straight-bar push-down
description: The blood flow restriction (BFR) underhand straight-bar push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, straight-bar grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
benefits:
BFR training boosts metabolic stress in the muscle, creating a strong muscular growth stimulus at light weight
Cable provides constant tension throughout the movement, including at peak contraction
Great for time-efficient arm training or after heavy pressing workouts
Focuses stress on the medial and long head of the triceps
Many lifters "feel" the peak contraction better using an underhand grip

name: BFR overhand straight-bar push-down
description: The blood flow restriction (BFR) overhand straight-bar push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, straight-bar grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
benefits:
BFR training boosts metabolic stress in the muscle, creating a strong muscular growth stimulus at light weight
Cable provides constant tension throughout the movement, including at peak contraction
Great for time-efficient arm training or after heavy pressing workouts
Straight-bar grip focuses stress on the medial and lateral heads of the triceps

name: BFR cable rope push-down
description: The blood flow restriction (BFR) cable rope push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, rope grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
benefits:
BFR training boosts metabolic stress in the muscle, creating a strong muscular growth stimulus at light weight
A rope grip allows more shoulder extension, activating the long head of the triceps
Great for time-efficient arm training or after heavy pressing workouts
Many lifters "feel" the peak contraction better using a rope grip

name: BFR cable rope hammer curl
description: The blood flow restriction (BFR) cable rope hammer curl is an arm movement that builds biceps size and strength using a cable stack, rope grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
benefits:
BFR training boosts metabolic stress in the muscle, creating a muscular growth stimulus at light weight
Cable provides constant tension throughout the movement, including at peak contraction
Great for time-efficient arm training or after heavy pulling workouts
Trains the biceps, forearms, brachialis, and brachioradialis
Effective at building biceps thickness, helping boost the peak from below

name: ACFT Hand-release push-up
description: The hand-release push-up is a variation of the push-up, a popular bodyweight exercise commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a movement to build upper-body strength and endurance, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core
Increases core strength and hip stability
Engages lower-body muscles to maintain plank position
Part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT
Can add pauses or manipulate tempo to increase difficulty

name: Hand shift plank
description: The hand shift plank is a progression of the straight-arm plank exercise where you maintain a plank position as you shift your hands side to side. The additional movement forces the core muscles to work harder to stabilize.
benefits:
More difficult than the traditional straight-arm plank
Increased core engagement due to extra movement
Develops and strengthens core stabilizer muscles

name: Side-lying leg adduction scissor
description: The side-lying leg adduction scissor is a dynamic core exercise that combines the isometric hold of a side-lying leg lift with leg adductions to further challenge the core and adductors. It targets multiple muscles of the core, primarily the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
benefits:
Isometric hold builds strength in the abdominals
Co-contraction of core and adductor muscles
Engages lower-body muscles, especially the quads, hip flexors, and adductors

name: 1.5-rep push-up
description: The 1.5-rep push-up is a more difficult variation of the push-up, commonly used to train for military and tactical physical fitness tests. It builds upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, core, upper back, triceps, and shoulders.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core
Increases upper-body strength and core stability
Engages lower-body muscles to maintain plank position
More difficult progression of the standard bodyweight push-up
Can add additional pauses or manipulate tempo to increase difficulty

name: ACFT Triple-clap push-up
description: The triple-clap push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, core, and shoulders.
benefits:
Strengthens the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core
Targets the powerful fast-twitch muscle fibers
Carries over to increased speed and strength in pressing movements
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds endurance, balance, and coordination
Requires no equipment

name: Sprinter burpee
description: The sprinter burpee is an explosive version of the burpee exercise that adds a sprinter jump to the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
benefits:
Builds muscular endurance and strength in the lower and upper body
Requires core and lower back strength to keep a neutral spine during the push-up and sprinter jump
Improves explosiveness and power
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds endurance, balance, and coordination
Requires no equipment

name: ACFT Superman push-up
description: The Superman push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core that involves pressing up off the floor and lifting the hands and feet off the ground simultaneously at the top of the movement.
benefits:
Explosive push-up, plyometric push-up
Targets the powerful fast-twitch muscle fibers
Carries over to increased speed and strength in pressing movements
Cardiovascular challenge that also builds endurance, balance, and coordination
Requires no equipment

name: Cross-body plank march
description: The cross-body plank march is an exercise targeting the entire core but especially the obliques. It’s more difficult than a standard plank, with the extra stabilization challenge of bringing one knee at a time off the ground toward the opposing elbow. This will increase the challenge to the core and shoulder muscles, but also present a coordination and balance challenge.
benefits:
Works the obliques and deep core or transversus abdominis
More challenging than standard planks
Helps develop balance, focus, and body awareness

name: Incline band bench press
description: The incline band bench press is variation of the incline press, a popular upper-body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
benefits:
